text: in some recent videos in some of our
repos or even on X you might have seen
this and you might have asked what is
this thing i want to give a quick
overview of what this is it's called
Langraph Studio this is a specialized
IDE for working with and debugging graph
agents so I'll show it working right now
this is with a pretty popular project we
have called local deep researcher and
you'll see right here is a graph we'll
talk about this a little bit later
you'll see right here is an input pane
where I can add user input and I can hit
submit now as this is running you can
see what's happening in the graph we
generate a query and while this is
happening you can follow along over here
to see as your graph state is populated
here's our query generation here are the
results of web search for example here
is summarization and we can see it's
streaming and this particular graph
repeats with a process of reflection
sization for some defined number of
cycles and again in studio we can see
everything happening as our graph is
going through this process now our graph
finished running and you can see over
here we can actually scroll through
everything that happened over the course
of the graph's execution and in
particular we can see at every single
node in our graph how the state was
updated so I want to take a little bit
of time to build up an understanding of
studio from the core components and
really break down what's happening under
the hood when we're actually using it so
first langraph studio is part of what we
call the broader langraph platform so
langap platform is a number of
components that work together to support
developing deploying and debugging
monitoring langap applications and you
can kind of think about this in a few
different ways so there is typically
your agent or application architecture
that can involve a few different things
it can involve langchain integrations
for models vector stores or other things
it can include langraph for
orchestration and it can include tools
that agents you build can invoke now you
can easily implement Lang graph
applications in for example a Jupyter
notebook you can test them there that's
not a problem langraph platform is a way
to actually deploy them and to connect
them to a few different useful things
one is memory so Langraph platform has
built-in short-term and long-term memory
short-term memory is what we call thread
memory so that's memory that persists
across a given user interaction and
long-term memory persists across many
different threads or many different user
interactions so like memories about a
user for example you may want to save
that can be done in long-term memory and
when you deploy your agent or
application with Minecraft server it
connects to studio which we'll talk
about in a lot of depth but also as
you'll see it connects to Langmith which
gives you lots of useful observability
features so really the core piece to
take away from this is Langraph Studio
is a part of this broader Langraph
platform this platform gives you a very
easy way to develop deploy and debug
applications built in Langraph and now
this server can be run locally on your
machine or hosted and we'll talk about
that more in a little bit so as we saw
before studio is a specialized IDE it
can connect to Langraph server and
enables visualization interaction
debugging of the application now to use
Lang platform and in turn langraph
studio you do have to structure your
application in a certain way it's pretty
straightforward the central piece is
this configuration file and I'll show
you specifically in the local deep
researcher repo and you can see it here
the key things to note are definition of
dependencies this langraph configuration
file environment and then this we'll
talk about in a bit but this is just
your graph implementation so here's our
repo local deep researcher here is at
langraph.json we can actually see what's
going on here so you can see this points
to your graphs you can see that the
compile graph is specified here and
that's exactly what we point to in
line.json you can see we point to the
directory the file name and the compile
graph name so that's how this
configuration file points to the
specific compile graph that you want to
load and run with langraph platform and
in addition studio the application
structure includes dependencies in this
case I use pi project autotoml here it
is and as shown the graph definition and
you'll notice in a lot of example repos
graph definitions often split up so you
have kind of a graph.py often times this
has the final compile graph but then you
can take your state your prompts and
utils and those can be put in separate
files that you just pull in to your
graph.py finally the environment file
which will be loaded using python.in now
if you're running locally you don't
actually need an env file it can read
any environment variables just from your
Python interpreter environment but it's
often good practice to include it i want
to just show how to run LRAP platform
locally on your machine for development
purposes and all you need to do
following these instructions are install
the Langraph CLI as noted here and run
langraph dev now you notice in a lot of
repos I provide this shortcut and I want
to explain what's happening here a
little bit so this uses a tool called
uvx to create and manage a virtual
environment for your langraph
application and launch the local
langraph development server so uvs is an
environment manager creates an isolated
environment for python applications
we'll create a fresh environment when we
run now this specifies that the
environment should include what we just
talked about the langraph cli package
with inmemory extras for running it
locally in development mode that's all
that means then that with editable just
installs the current directory or your
application in editable mode changes to
code will be immediately reflected
without needing to reinstall your
package specify Python version and then
run langraph.dev so this command will
launch langraph server in memory mode
locally on your machine so as an example
I'm in that local deep researcher
project and this is that command we just
saw i can just run and there you go
you're going to see this welcome to
Langraph and you're gonna see
automatically server spins up in your
browser now if you go back you also have
some links to interesting things here
you have a direct link to the API you
have a direct link to API docs you can
open this up and you can see the full
API docs laid out for you with all the
different endpoints available on your
locally running server you can see it's
organized by assistance thread and so
forth and now this link you can see is
studio UI so it automatically spun up
but you can also just click on it and
that opens studio so when studio opens
you're going to notice a few different
things so first is you can see langraph
platform studio identified here at the
top and there's this thing up here so
what's this well if you go back to your
langraph.json we can look in our
directory here open up the langraph.json
you see when you defined your graphs
here you name the graph in this
particular case we named it researcher
and it pointed to the compile graph as
we saw in graph.py pi and this name is
just reflected over in studio so that's
basically the name of your graph now you
can have multiple graphs specified in
one leg json file and then you can
actually just scroll through them in
studio very easily now the second thing
to highlight is you see your graph and
each of these things in the graph
reflected here in studio correspond to
nodes actually defined in your graph so
we can go ahead and look at
langraph.json we can see this points to
our graph itself we can go there and
look and so here's
graph.py here's our node definitions you
can see there's a node for generate
query that has all the logic into there
a node for web research now go back to
studio that node is reflected generate
query then web research so the flow of
information through your graph as
specified in graph.py pi through the
node definitions and the connectivity
between the nodes using edges are all
represented here in your graph
visualization so this visualization maps
one one to what's laid out in the
corresponding in this case graph.py
that's the second thing to recognize now
this input where is this coming from if
you go back to our code and go down to
state graph builder you can see when we
lay this out we actually supply the
state to our graph with an overall graph
state as well as an input and an output
so what does this mean well the input is
just the actual input state fields that
we want the user to see likewise the
output is just the output state that we
want returned ultimately when we run the
graph now if you look at that summary
state input you can go to state.py
pi and you can see it just contains a
single field research topic which is
also duplicated in summary state this
represents the full state of our graph
but this input is only things we want
the user to see if you go over to studio
you can see we only expose research
topic to the user which is often nice
because we don't want to expose for
example all the possible state variables
that are present within our graph to the
user now as we saw before we can go
ahead and supply an input and we can see
pass an input and our graph runs
initially it's running generate query we
can see it streams as it's going web
search is done when web search is done
we can actually can go and inspect all
the results from web search and as we
saw before we see state streaming as a
graph is running so in particular this
summary sources node is actually running
and we can see what is being returned
now it's kind of interesting thing when
each node finishes you can actually see
the state key that's been updated and
the value of the state key so while it
was running we saw the output stream but
then when it finishes you can actually
see the assignment to the corresponding
state key let's look at the code briefly
to understand what's happening here so
you can see this state key is running
summary and here's what we got if we
look at graph.py Pi go that summarize
sources node we can see we need a whole
bunch of stuff in here but ultimately
again we update that running summary
state key with our running summary and
that's exactly what you can see running
summary and then the value shown to us
in studio so really the way to think
about this is as your graph is running
when each node finishes you can actually
look at the state updates made by that
particular node so our graph finished we
can see something kind of interesting
all those state updates made over the
course execution we can scroll through
and if you look at the top here you see
this thread UU ID identified so what's
happening here when you execute this in
Langraph platform it's automatically
saved to a thread and what's really nice
is these threads are actually persisted
for you so if you click on this you
actually can go and scroll through your
prior executions so here's a number of
other graph executions that I've run in
this particular project and these are
all persisted for me now in addition if
I click on this memory button this takes
me to any long-term or across thread
memories that explicitly saved to the
Langraph store we have some other videos
on that which I'll link the Langraph
store allows you to save things
specifically that can be accessed across
all the different threads we just showed
this particular graph doesn't use the
store but we do have a number of other
examples that do i just want to
highlight it as another thing that's
accessible to you within studio directly
so you can see anything that's been
saved to store right here in addition to
all your prior threads and I'll show you
something else that I use quite a bit at
the end of this overall thread open run
in Langsmith click that and it takes you
directly to the corresponding Langsmith
trace for that particular run and within
the Langsmith trace one thing I like to
do just click on this thread view and we
can look at then right here that same
thread that we just were examining in
studio but here we can actually look
really under the hood at every single
model call and all the different nodes
so it's just kind of another way of
seeing what happened within your graph
but in this case looking at the Langmith
trace specifically which allows you to
really dig into any particular model
call if you want so this is the lowest
level of it but what's nice is it's one
one with everything that we can see here
in studio so I often like to run in
studio first which is a great way to
kind of visualize the overflow of my
graph to look at the outputs and easily
open up langmmith if I need to really
dig in under the hood further on any
particular model calls or other things
now the final thing I want to show just
as an introduction to Langraph Studio is
actually one of the features that I use
quite a bit and I really like if you
click on this manage configurations tab
this is where you actually can save
different configurations of your graph
so for this local deep researcher I have
a DeepSseek R18B configuration and this
runs this particular local model
Deepseek R18B with Lama with a
particular search provider but what's
nice is I can set up other assistants
easily this is a different one that uses
R11.5B i can set this to active here and
now this is actually the active
assistant in studio i can create a new
thread just like this and I can run my
new assistant if I want to now these
configurations where are these coming
from and how do they relate to the code
so if I go back to the code click on
configuration.py this is actually where
all the fields in my configuration are
specified in this case with defaults
which in studio are expressed through
this nice UI and I can easily update or
overwrite any of those defaults to
create what we call an assistant an
assistant is just a particular
combination of configurations so I can
click new here i can create a new
assistant name set the research depth
set the model I want to use the pervama
you get the idea the point is that it's
really easy to configure specific
assistants and save them so I can easily
reference them and run them quickly in
studio this is one of the most useful
things because if I want to for example
test different configurations in this
case different models very quickly I can
do that really easily so that kind of
gives you a brief tour of langraph
studio and again just to summarize
langraph studio is part of langraph
platform in this case it's run locally
on my machine this graph definition
comes from that langraph.json JSON which
specifies the compile graph I want to
load this input is basically the input
state schema which is specified in my
case in state.py every execution of this
graph is captured within a thread those
threads can be browsed very easily here
every thread links to corresponding
langsmith trace so I can really dig into
what happened under the hood and I can
man and run different assistants very
easily here so I have control over my
configurations here i have control over
all my prior executions and visibility
into them here and all those linked over
to Langsmith for detailed debugging and
observability so that's how studio
connects into the idea of langraph
platform and how it ties into langmmith
here and how you can use it for
debugging your langraph applications
really easily so hopefully this provides
kind of an overview of what studio is
and how it works and we'll have some
follow-ups digging into some of the more
specific features like human and loop
within studio but I did just want to
give this kind of overview of how to
think about studio and how to use it
thanks
